Award.AwardTitle: The CECS Student Success Scholarship Program: Leveraging Curricular Innovation in Engineering and Computer Science Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is providing scholarships to academically talented and financially needy students across all disciplines of engineering and computer science at Wright State University, with a particular focus on the recruitment and retention of underrepresented students. By increasing the number of academically talented engineering and computer science graduates, the institution is directly contributing to the technology-based economy in the Dayton region and beyond.

The technical aspects of the project feature the formation of student cohorts from both first-year and transfer students participating in Wright State's National Model for Engineering Mathematics Education and related interventions. Student learning communities specifically for S-STEM scholars support their success in EGR 101 Introductory Mathematics for Engineering Applications. Separate S-STEM learning communities for computer science majors support their success in a newly redesigned SCALE-UP curriculum (based on a successful model adapted from physics education reform efforts). All S-STEM scholars receive student support and enrichment activities from first-year through graduation, including mandatory, individualized academic advising each term, peer mentoring and tutoring programs, undergraduate research, internship and co-op opportunities, undergraduate teaching and K-12 outreach opportunities, and other co-curricular interventions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has leveraged Wright State University's first-year curricular innovations -  including its NSF funded National Model for Engineering Mathematics Education and its student-centered active learning environment (SCALE-UP) for computer science - through the award of S-STEM scholarships to academically talented and financially needy students across all disciplines in the College of Engineering and Computer Science (CECS).  Specific goals have included measurable increases in the enrollment, diversity and retention of our academically talented and financially needy students.  Project activities have supported the goals of the S-STEM program through 1) Improved educational opportunities for students through targeted recruitment activities, with a particular focus on underrepresented groups; 2) Increased retention of students through participation in proven curricular innovations; 3) Improved student support programs from first-year through graduation; 4) Increased numbers of well-educated and skilled employees through exposure to undergraduate research, internship and co-op opportunities.

Over the course of the five-year project duration, a total of 109 students have been awarded S-STEM scholarships. As part of the annual project evaluation, focus group students have consistently reported that the scholarship awards were a critical factor in their decision to attend Wright State.  This suggests that the successful integration of the S-STEM scholarship program with the college's overall recruitment strategy has been an effective contributor to the growth of its undergraduate enrollments, which reached all-time record highs in each of the first three years of the project.  While the recruitment strategies employed in this S-STEM program have not been particularly effective in broadening racial and ethnic diversity, they have been highly effective in broadening the participation of women.  Moreover, retention and graduation rates for the initial cohorts have indicated that students recruited to our program with S-STEM scholarships have been more likely to persist and graduate than the general population of similarly qualified students.  

Overall, the results of this project suggest that the appropriate allocation of S-STEM scholarship awards in conjunction with proven first-year curricular innovations can have a measurable impact on the recruitment and retention of engineering and computer science students, while broadening the participation of underrepresented groups.
